P.FONT: Very intense- as it is just a little sample from the middle of a track- it's quite jarring, presumably the whole track would build and build to this point so as not to be as sudden and intense. alwo very very busy- hard to focus on or define, but this may also be a product of the lack of build up etc.
quite groovy- instantly likeable and boppy. coherent and well formulated. essentially successful snip of music.

try and find how the two meet- get down to the bare essence of the source and target- look at similarity and difference. see how if it's appropriate to speed up from one tempo to the other, or if a drop out of rythum altogether would be more appropriate. see which elements of source and target go well together, and which don't.

Brake the source down, strip it back to some essential elements- then start to change those elements, bringing the tempo up to match the target, slowly bringing in the beat from the target, merging stripped back bones of the two tracks, then let the source elements go and start adding more elements if the target.

tempo is a big one, there is a bit of a gap to bridge here. also metre, as we a going from straight 4/4 to something more swung. pitch would also be an issue, but I would personally strip both tracks back to rhythmic and textural back-bones for transition to avoid any problems in this area.

hmmm... it is quite chaotic, and the decreasing pitch makes something quite sinister and not really pleasant. while both source and target melodies/pitch elements work in thier own right, the pitch elements of the morph are not really pleasing. the rhythmic side of things, while managing to bridge the gap, is not really pleasing to the ear either, very shambling and chaotic, while both source and target are quite defined and ordered. Although- upon second listening, it does work to some degree- and considering the verry short time over which the morph occurs, is quite successful. I would think that a morph between this source and targett should take longer, as the differences a quite large, and the are lots of changes to occur.

I had a different response on first and second listens- first was perceived as less smooth, second was smoother. don't know if that helps. the perceived level of smoothness has a verry strong effect on the response to the transition, both when listening critically, and in a more real-world context I beleive- as it seems to me to be one of the major reasons to create a morph, for a smooth transition.

certain elements, such as the pitch shifting between source and target, which I found to be 'not smooth' could be effective in creating a kind of warpy, nightmary kind of esthetic- which could be quite successful if desired.
kind of negative
pitch drop synth thing- as mentionedpreviously- quite nightmarish... could be efffective if desired.
good
it's good when the beat of the source finally comes in- feels conclusive, picks up.
It gets more acceptable the more I hear it- quite strange. IT is definately getting there- but I really think it should go for longer- make the journey less jarring.

I would stripp back on the synth stuff in the transition- I feel they don't warp aswell, and aren't really necessary during the warp. as mentioned- I would make it longer- and would try to marry the rhythmic elements better (maybe not as easy as it sounds). beat kind of seems to drop out, it looses it's pace.

I feel this one is much stronger- the stripping right back approach is more succesful- and when the drop of the new rythm section comes in, it is very stronger- much better than the fade in of the last morph. yeah- that drop is really really good! ;-]

I have only rated this morph as 5 on smoothness- but I would give it 7 for effectiveness- the drop into the new beat is not really smooth- but it's perfect. so smoothness is only required when appropriate.
yes- efffective as mentioned.
good
good strip down to basic elements that will warp well
GREAT
new beat comes in with heaps of energy at just the right time- perfect.

Yes- very palatable- very good for dancefloor- that drop is perfect for dancefloor engergy- people would love it. as for computer game- would need to beb very punctual moment in game- as very big change, the drop would need to signify soemthing- big change of pace in game.
nope-0 really no changes to this one- it be phat ;-]
kind of cheasy, not really my kind of thing- jazz motif- but verry synthetc execution- not a good look... too slow to beb successful.
hmm- strange- it works because it's fast, not sure I like the timbre of the sounds (don't want to offend anyone here- just baring my personal opinion to keep responses accurate and relevant ;-)
see if we can get the second tune to sit double time with the first tune
strip back to a few basic elements- maybe drop the beat out of the source for a phrase, but keep other elements- then bring in beat only of source- then replace other elements.
tempo- could work easy as double time- not sure how melodies will morph- maybe strip them out for trans.
kind of weak... didn't really work for me- just didn't have any highlights...
I give this one very smooth- as it was very gradual and smooth- yet I felt this was unsuccessful. smooth transition- but not pleasing result.
neg.
synthy squelch starts fading in, doesn't seem to work-
medium
glitchy bits of faster beat start to come in- works okay- but could be more effective.
maybe not too palatable- but it is smooth enough to not be too Jarring- just not really pleasing or successful.
make the transitions faster- more succinct. less fad in and out- more drops.
ditto
reasonably strong- new beat comes in well- but the medoies seem to kind of wobble and wash from one to the other- not solid enough.

really quite smooth, but only some elements were successful. rhythmic transitions were very good- and dropped in rather than being smooth (but dropped in very not jarring way)- melody follows very smooth transition- too smooth- meandering.
ditto
good
target beat comes in- nice drop- not fade- successful
good
beat drops out again- then comes back to solidify it's presence- works.
works in dancefloor context succesfully increases pace and takes it up. not jarring.
hmmm.... hard with this one- nope- really can't pick what i would change...
weakish- very stange meody- doesn't sit for me at all rhythm is okay though.
cool and eerie- would be good for computer game... mysterious yet full of action- killing zombies or something ;-]

I keep coming back to the same thing- which may be just my way of doing things- but I would definately try to loose the melodic elements of the source before bring any of the elements of the target into the picture. the difference in melodic content is too vast, the mood and feel too different- and I really don't think the would sit together.
break source down to rhythmic essentials- bring in rhythmic elements of target- let them gell- take bring in other elements of target- drop out rest of source...

weak- very chaoatic- kind of depressing- very dischordant- melodic elements really don't gell. too smooth-

very smooth- affect is negativve. too smooth- they don't go well over one-another, so the changes neep to be more sudden, not a slow melding, the melding of all colours of the rainbow results in grey-brown murk.

neg.
target melody starts to encroach immediately sounds dischordant.
pos.
starts to sound better as melody of source is left behind- the conflict is released
pos.
target track properly resolves, is released from the confines of the source elements, which have been holding it back.

too wack- dischordant for dancefloor- potentially appropriate for part in computergame where everything is peachy- then the zombies are approaching, everything goes awry- hence the dischordance would be appropriate- then the eerie zombie track kicks in proper.
changegs need to be more sudden- melody of source left, melody of target embraced- don't gell well as blend. beats could also drop out / in in similar fashion.
stronger- still not sure about the melody meldings- but they work much bettter than previous. beat drops in very nicely- altogether very successful.

while elements of the morph were quite smooth, others were more abrupt- like beat drop. smoothing the textural melodic elements was acheived better here- and the more abrupt drops if beat were much more affective.

yep- would work in both contexts, succesful high energy change for livev electronica- successful mood change for computer game.
just loose some of melodic elements in middle of transition- strip it back more, less conflict between source and target. all esle works.
hmm.. interesting- kind of la la techno- not sure if i like the esthetic- not sure what else to say about it...
this has more motivation and groove- good feel, not sure about darker squelchy synth timbre with happy lead synth, don't work very well together...

this seems to be an easy task- both have a happy feel and similar tempo- the melodies could be a continuation of one another, and I would make the change between melodies sudden and immedite- as if the melody follows straight on into the new phrase- like a verse-chorus key change or something. rhythm could perhaps be replaced gradually- not too sure.... but think it would be the easiest morph of the lot.
ditto
ditto
quite strong- quite subtle- which is possible beacause the source and target are closer to one another.

very smooth- and perhaps the only truely successful example of smooth morphing so far. melodies sit together okay, as the key is similar, and tempo doesn't need to change too much. rhythm feel is the biggest difference between tracks- and while the smoth transition is certainly successfull- could perhaps be more punctual with a sudden change between rhythms.
pos.
melodic elements of target introduced and being to sit well
pos.
beat of target setlles in, sounds very good.
would work in both these contexts, successful.

make the morph longer- really enjoy the drop of the target house beat, maybe strip back to beat and one other element only- not because it is required for the morph to succeed- but because it would be phat ;-]
yeah- this ones great! pretty much employs all the elements i thought the first one was missing.
this one is still quite smooth, but has more drop type movements- more energy- more poignant.

pos.

yep- very good for both contexts, would perhaps go unnoticed as a transition- seem more like new movement in same track- but this is due to similarity of source and target.
hmmm... this one is pretty good- yep- like it just the way it is.

I havve been producing electronic music for about 3 years- and djing different styles and genres of electronic / hiphop music for about 4. I spend alot of time looking at how different genres can be mixed and gelled- botht in dj and producing conttexts.

my answers were very re-occuring throughout the questionaire- I kept saying the same things about each morph- reacting to certain morph techniques / elements is similar ways. there are obviously value in these patterns. also- the morphing explored here deals mainly with midi- not sure how this applies / fits alongside wave-based morhing- or how the results woud be if the questionare was based on wave morhping... things could be very different. the tracks in the questionare seem to use alot of the same / similar synth programs- which may have an impact on the results of the questionare- if source and target were written by different people with different programs- the morphs may be alot different- potentially harder.
2 hours
